abstract.text: An object that displays an alert message.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use this class to configure alerts and action sheets with the message that you want to display and the actions from which to choose. After configuring the alert controller with the actions and style you want, present it using the
method. UIKit displays alerts and action sheets modally over your app’s content.
In addition to displaying a message to a user, you can associate actions with your alert controller to give people a way to respond. For each action you add using the

method, the alert controller configures a button with the action details. When a person taps that action, the alert controller executes the block you provided when creating the action object. The following code shows how to configure an alert with a single action.

code: let alert = UIAlertController(title: "My Alert", message: "This is an alert.", preferredStyle: .alert)
alert.addAction(UIAlertAction(title: NSLocalizedString("OK", comment: "Default action"), style: .default, handler: { _ in

inlineContent.text: When configuring an alert with the

style, you can also add text fields to the alert interface. The alert controller lets you provide a block for configuring your text fields prior to display. The alert controller maintains a reference to each text field so that you can access its value later.
class is intended to be used as-is and doesn’t support subclassing. The view hierarchy for this class is private and must not be modified.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
An action that can be taken when the user taps a button in an alert.
An object that displays an alert message.
Constants indicating the type of alert to display.
An alert displayed modally for the app.
The actions that the user can take in response to the alert or action sheet.
Attaches an action object to the alert or action sheet.
Adds a text field to an alert.
Creates and returns a view controller for displaying an alert.
Descriptive text that provides more details about the reason for the alert.
The preferred action for the user to take from an alert.
The style of the alert controller.
Indicates the severity of the alert.
The array of text fields displayed by the alert.
The title of the alert.
Constants for specifying the severity of an alert in apps built with Mac Catalyst.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the
API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The interface that determines if an object supports a spring-loaded interaction for drag and drop activities.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Presents a view controller modally.
Present important information to the user or prompt the user about an important choice.

doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKi.title: Getting the user’s attention with alerts and action sheets

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
